Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Synthesis and Characterization of End-Functionalized Starches for Generating Functional Hybrid Polymers and Novel Self-Assembled Architectures
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Peter M. Iovine of the University of San Diego will develop new chemistries to functionalize starch-based polymeric materials and to incorporate them into more complex macromolecular architectures. Starch is a versatile polymeric materials platform due to its abundance, biodegradability, biocompatibility, structural diversity, and molecular recognition behavior. The research objectives include studying and optimizing chain end-modifying reactions that lead to the installation of click synthons, developing a new class of natural-synthetic hybrid polymer featuring amylose or amylopectin side chains, and synthesizing and studying amylose-based self-assembled polymers. The broader impacts focus primarily on the high quality mentoring of undergraduate and postdoctoral researchers. Beyond these core outcomes, the project impacts include curriculum development, community outreach activities, and the support of interdisciplinary research in the undergraduate environment.

Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life that utilize plastics, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. Polymers can be classified as either naturally occurring or synthetic, meaning they have been synthesized using raw materials that can be traced back to petrochemicals. This research explores the preparation of hybrid polymers, consisting of a combination of both natural and synthetic polymers. More specifically, this research focuses on studying and utilizing starch, an abundant and cheap raw material, as the natural component of the hybrid polymers. Such fundamental knowledge about starch chemistry could lead to new technologies for biomedical materials, personal care products, and packaging materials, amongst many possible uses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in an entirely new class of hybrid polymeric material that contains both natural and synthetic components. Prior to our work there were limited synthetic methods to chemically link these two very different types of polymers (natural and synthetic) in a manner that gives solution processible materials. Solution processibility is an important characteristic as it facilitates the production of films and coatings and therefore increases the versatility of the polymers.  In this multi-year project, we successfully synthesized a hybrid polymer that brought together starch (biopolymer) with a polyester (synthetic polymer). The project made the following contributions to the field of polymer chemistry:

1) We achieved the first synthesis of a hybrid polymer where the starch polymer chains were grafted to the backbone of a synthetic polymer. We further demonstrated that this type of polymer architecture (brush) was versatile and produced a solution processible hybrid polymer.

2) We were the first research group to report the production of thin films from this type of starch-containing hybrid polymer.

3) Thin films of these starch-containing polymers were evaluated as anti-fouling coatings–materials that resist surface contamination. The hybrid polymers performed comparably, if not better, than widely used all-synthetic polymers. This is an important finding as replacing all, or a portion, of a material’s petroleum-derived chemicals with a natural polymer represents a step toward sustainability. In addition, since starch is biocompatible and biodegradable, these materials may open-up opportunities in the biomedical sciences.

4) We substantially broadened the utility of polysaccharides, but especially starch, in the development of these new materials. The synthetic chemistry developed and exploited over the four-year project puts our group and other researchers in a position to think more creatively about incorporating polysaccharides into functional materials (e.g. bioplastics). We see this as a significant advance.

The broader impacts of this project were:

1) An increased understanding of how to manipulate the structure of biopolymers so that they can be used in novel materials applications. We published several papers on this topic during the funding period; these papers are now being cited by other researchers and advancing the state-of-the art in polysaccharide utilization.

2) The training of both postdoctoral researchers and undergraduate students. Two postdoctoral researchers were mentored by the PI during this project period. Both postdocs are now professors at primarily undergraduate institutions where they are balancing teaching, research, and service. The training they received, in conjunction with this award, prepared them for a career that creatively intertwines teaching and research. The work also involved 17 undergraduate research students. All of the students have benefited from the research experience; many have presented at national conferences and/or have been included as co-authors on peer-review publications. Undergraduate students participating in this research have since moved-on to careers in the health sciences, biotechnology sector, or are pursuing advanced degrees in the chemical sciences.


Last Modified: 11/29/2017
Modified by: Peter M Iovine

The hybrid polymers performed comparably, if not better, than widely used all-synthetic polymers.
